prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Using 12m-array (array configuration: C34-1) + ACA (7m-array + Total power array), we will observe OMC-1N, OMC-2, OMC-3, and OMC-1 (Blue rectangles in Figure 1 left panel) in CS (6–5), N2H+ (3–2), and C33S (6-5), simultaneously with the velocity resolution of ~0.03 km s?1. The 1.1 mm continuum emission will be obtained simultaneously spending one base band as the TDM mode (band width of 2 GHz). The region will be covered with the six science goals and field settings are summarized in Table 1. In this specific science goal, we request 87 pointing mosaic observations (53”x156”) for covering the OMC-3 region.
In order to surely detect sources in the low-mass end, we request the 1? continuum noise level of 0.37mJy/beam, which corresponds to 54s of on-source integration. This corresponds to the 5sigma mass sensitivity of 0.006 Mo. The sensitivity is sufficient enough to detect proto-brown dwarf mass cores. For the line observations, we will achieve the 1sigma noise level of 100 mJy/beam km/s with the velocity resolution of 0.03 km/s. This corresponds to a 5sigma mass sensitivity limit of roughly10^-4 Mo.
This is a pilot observation for future large-scale imaging on the entire ISF, which will be performed efficiently once the On-The-Fly Interferometric (OTFI) imaging mode will be available.
Our line observations will request the highest velocity resolution (~0.03 km/s) in order to detect the local collapse (order of 0.1 km/s). Therefore, we request the higher data rate (16.49 MB/s) than the maximum data rate described in the technical handbook (12MB/s).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Filamentary molecular clouds are very common in star forming regions, where they typically connect to a central hub/stellar cluster. However, observationally it is still not well quantified if or how the filaments feed material into the hub and how this affects their fragmentation – crucial observations for a proper understanding of cluster formation. We propose to do an ALMA study of how the Orion integral shaped filament (ISF) is collapsing and fragmenting into dense cores. We already analyzed the fragmentation scale of the ISF using the Submillimeter Array, where we identified ~70 dense cores and found that the fragmentation length decreases with decreasing distance to the center (OMC1). The ISF collapse occurs both locally and globally and we aim to disentangle these motions using ALMA to map in CS (6-5) and N2H+ (3-2) three different high-density regions along the ISF (OMC1, OMC2 and OMC3) at high angular and velocity resolution. The comparison of the kinematical behavior of these regions will allow us to quantify which collapse (global or local) is more dominant in each region, and how the filament feeds material on the central cluster whilst still fragmenting.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
